application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

p.s: In this issue of Molecular Cell, Zhang et al. (2017) systematically identify proteins interacting with all possible di-ubiquitin linkages, thus providing a catalog of readers of the ubiquitin code.

Ubiquitination is an incredibly versatile modification: an E2/E3 ligase complex can attach a single ubiquitin to a single (monoubiquitination) or several lysines (multi-monoubiquitination) in target proteins.
Moreover, ubiquitin can itself be ubiquitinated, which results in polyubiquitin chains (polyubiquitination).

These linkages can occur via any of the seven lysine residues or the amino terminus of ubiquitin and result in homotypic (always the same linkage), heterotypic (different linkages), and even branched polyubiquitin chains.
Reminiscent of a code, the different linkage types have distinct conformations and can lead to different biological outcomes (Komander and Rape, 2012).
E2/E3 ligase complexes correspond to ''writers'' of the code that generate specific ubiquitin linkages (Figure 1).
De-ubiquitinating enzymes (DUBs) ''erase'' the code by removing linkages.
But how is the code read and interpreted by cells?
Despite the identification of numerous ubiquitin-binding domains and proteins, this remains an interesting and challenging question.
Zhang and co-workers now present an interaction landscape of ubiquitin signaling (Zhang et al., 2017).
This paper establishes a new technology to study ubiquitin signaling and provides a valuable catalog of ''readers'' for specific diubiquitin signals.
Identifying readers of the ubiquitin code requires a method to detect linkage-specific interactions.
Zhang and co-workers achieved this by a clever combination of chemical biology and quantitative interaction proteomics.
First, they chemically synthesized all eight possible di-ubiquitins (diUbs).
They used non-hydrolyzable linkages since otherwise DUBs might cleave the dimers.
Second, they used these synthetic diUbs as bait to fish for binding partners in cell extracts.
Third, they identified proteins in these pulldowns by quantitative shotgun proteomics.
Quantification allowed them to distinguish between specific binders of a given linkage type and non-specific contaminants.
Applying this technology to HeLa cells, mouse embryonic stem cells, and neuronal precursor cells identified several hundred linkage-specific binders.

The results reflect known biology such as binding of the proteasome to K48 linkages, which mediates degradation, as well as association of the BRCA1-A complex with K63 linkages, which are involved in DNA damage repair.

In addition to these known examples, many proteins were newly identified as linkage-selective ubiquitin binders, hinting that the number of ubiquitin-recognizing domains exceeds the so far known classes.
For many proteins, the binding patterns were similar in the three cell lines, suggesting that linkage selectivity is conserved and cell-type independent.
Other proteins showed cell-type-specific differences that were consistent with cell-type-specific differences in their abundance.
Perhaps most interestingly, several proteins displayed cell-type-specific binding without apparent differences in their expression level.

In this case, the linkage selectivity might be due to differentially expressed co-factors or posttranslational modifications, like the previously described phosphorylation of ubiquitin (S65) as a regulator in the case of PINK1/Parkin (Wauer et al., 2015).

Relating the number of identified binders to the abundance of the different linkage types shows that the number of K48 and K63 recognizing proteins reflects the amount of K48 and K63 chains found in a cell (Na et al., 2012).
Surprisingly, a large number of binders were found for rare chains like linear and K33 chains.
This indicates that although these chains are of low abundance, they seem to be important signals, especially in neuronal cells.
Another interesting finding was that many DUBs preferred specific linkage types.
In some cases, DUBs bind specifically to linkages they cleave.
However, other DUBs bind to one type of linkage but deubiquitinate another.
The latter group of DUBs might thus remodel heterotypic/branched chains.
An important limitation of the new method is that it is based on an artificial pull-down in a cell-free system.
Therefore, it is not clear if this technique can also reveal stimulus-dependent binding within cells.
Zhang et al. investigated this question by looking at the DNA damage response.
They carried out K6 diUb pull-downs after inducing DNA damage and identified several proteins with increased binding, including the kinase CDK7 and the kinase inhibitor CDKN2A.
Using microscopy, they found that DNA damage also increases colocalization of both proteins with K6 chains in HeLa cells.
Hence, in vitro pull-downs with diUbs can in principle uncover stimulus-induced, linkage-specific binding in vivo.
Mass spectrometers have become invaluable tools to decipher the ubiquitin code.

They can be employed to identify ubiquitination sites, to assess the topology of ubiquitin chains, to characterize individual E3 and DUBs, and to study protein turnover (Xu and Peng, 2008;Xu et al., 2010;Mirzaei et al., 2010;Kim et al., 2011;Schwanh€ ausser et al., 2011;Wagner et al., 2011)
show that mass spectrometers can also identify readers of specific ubiquitin linkages in a systematic manner.
The new approach and the catalog of readers will stimulate further research projects.
For example, the in vivo relevance of most of the findings is not known and needs to be investigated in future studies.
Moreover, as the authors also acknowledge, their interaction landscape is by no means exhaustive.
It will be interesting to also look at branched chains, longer chains, and chains that contain additional modifications such as phosphorylated, acetylated, or sumoylated ubiquitin.
Ubiquitin is added to target substrates by E2/E3 ligase complexes (writers).
Ubiquitin can itself be ubiquitinated, which leads to di-ubiquitins with distinct conformations.
These conformations are recognized by linkage-specific binders that mediate cellular responses (readers 1 and 2).
Readers can themselves modify the ubiquitin chain.
For example, several deubiquitinating enzymes (DUBs) display linkage-specific binding and are thus both readers and erasers.
Figure 1.
Linkage-Selective Binding and the Ubiquitin Code
. Zhang et al. now Molecular Cell 65, March 2, 2017 ª 2017 Elsevier Inc. 779
780 Molecular Cell 65, March 2, 2017
